_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC operates an ethanol fuel production plant located in the city of Stockton, in San Joaquin County, California. As a requirement of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and Clean Air Act Amendments 112; Accidental Release of Hazardous Air Substances program, Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has completed a risk management plan for chemicals stored onsite above reporting thresholds. Regulated chemicals at Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC to include pentane (exceeds 10,000 pound threshold) and aqueous ammonia (exceeds 20,000 pound threshold).



Regulated Substances Handled

The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and process by products known as wet distillers' grain, distillers' syrup and distillers' corn oil, which are used as a livestock feed. Aqueous ammonia is stored onsite in liquid form in an above ground storage tank inside a secondary containment structure. Aqueous ammonia is used in the ethanol production process for pH control in the water and corn mash slurry as well as a nutrient for the growing yeast in fermentation. The maximum amount of aqueous ammonia stored is approximately 269,000 pounds (24 percent ammonia in water solution). The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (natural gasoline) blended with ethanol at approximately 2.5% to render the product unfit for human consumption prior to shipping.  Regulated chemicals at Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC include pentane (exceeds 10,000 pound threshold). The pentane is in a flammable mixture of Natural Gasoline (Denaturant).  Denaturant is stored in liquid form in an above ground storage vessel inside a secondary containment structure.  The maximum amount of denaturant on-site is approximately 412,000 pounds. Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has evaluated the worst-case and alternative case scenarios as they relate to the regulated substances. An Emergency Action Plan (Integrated Contingency Plan, or ICP)

for these scenarios has been prepared and implemented. Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities, is an active member of the Port of Stockton Foam Consortium, has sponsored and hosted emergency responder training.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol production process. It is the policy of Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws. In the event of an emergency, including an accidental release of flammables/toxics, it is the policy of Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC to notify the Stockton Fire Department and the County Sheriff according to the emergency action plan.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC has complied with the EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, as well as California regulations at CCR Title 8, Section 5189 and CCR Title 19 D-2, Chapter 4.5. Process safety information, safe work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and maintenance procedures are documented on-site as part of the facility PSM/RMP Prevention Program. Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis as outlined in the PSM/RMP Prevention Program. Audits of the overall RMP and Prevention Program are conducted on a regular basis.



Five-Year Accident History 

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC does not have a history of accidents related to RMP/CalARP regulated programs which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, evacuatio

ns or in-place sheltering in the last five years. The facility commenced operation fall of 2008.



Emergency Response Program 

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC is included in the community emergency response plan and has developed a written emergency action plan. This plan includes actions to minimize accidental releases of regulated substances, actions to inform the public and local agencies responding to accidental releases. Pacific Ethanol Stockton has provided a copy of the emergency action plan to the Stockton Fire Department and the County Environmental Health Department.  Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC conducts routine employee training on the plan and periodically evaluates the plan for necessary revisions.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC remains committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. Management is committed to promoting a safe work environment. Pacific Ethanol Stockton, LLC will continue to provide its employees with the necessary training, tools, and ongoing support needed to conduct their work safely and to operate the ethanol production process in a safe and efficient manner.  The facility has recently completed a compliance audit as well as a process hazard analysis and will work diligently to implement the recommendations.
